Award.AwardTitle: Search for new phases of the exotic superfluid 3He under nanoconfinement
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Abstract
Most consumer items utilize technology that emerged because of advances in condensed matter research. Future advances will be enabled by the sort of “curiosity driven” exploration of new regimes accessible only in a laboratory environment. The research to be conducted in this program will examine the special properties of superfluid 3He when confined in precisely defined structures less than a thousandth of a millimeter tall, marking the transition from bulk so-called 3 dimensional behavior to a new 2 dimensional regime. Undergraduate students and a Ph.D student will build on cutting edge knowledge to design and fabricate these structures opening up a new area of quantum nano-fluidics. The surfaces will have to have a well-defined smoothness since the smoothness (alterable with a coating of helium 4) changes the scattering at the surface much like a mirrored surface is different from a frosted surface. This scattering quality (together with the confinement) can also change the types of superfluid states (“phases”) that emerge. These phases should show a property “chirality” that should have properties like a spinning top. These new phases should exhibit novel characteristics such as highly conducting “edge states” that are scientifically “exciting” and that could, in the future form the basis of new types of devices for metrology and computation. Past graduate students and undergraduates of this team have gone on to productive careers in academia, high-technology industries and the financial sector, and the planned research will prepare a new generation of students for challenging careers.

Technical abstract:
Superfluid 3He can inform research activity that extends across many fields in Physics. The project combines nanofluidics (intricate and precisely fabricated silicon cavities with sizes tuned to the scale of the superfluid’s coherence length) with low temperature physics, to expose new size effects. The experimental activity will probe excitations using transport (superfluid density and heat conductivity) as well as novel noise thermometry and a nanowire to act as local thermometers. Researchers expect that entirely new p-wave superfluid states can be stabilized by such confinement and the balance between the superfluid ground state that preserves (3He-B) or breaks (3He-A) time reversal symmetry will also be affected by confinement. By measuring the phase diagram of confined 3He, details of the pressure and temperature dependence of the strong coupling strength will be mapped out allowing for more reliable prediction of the phase diagrams of 3He under confinement. Confinement will also provide the means to study the surface/edge excitations emerging as a result of bulk/edge correspondence. Studies of the hysteresis in the first-order transition between the confined A and B phases (radically different from nucleation in bulk) will challenge current understanding of these quantum transitions. New geometries will explore the physics of quantum transport across single and multiple interfaces. By combining low temperatures and nano fabrication, graduate students and undergraduates will be exposed to the exciting training ground that has prepared scientists for lead roles in academia and high-technology industries. Eventually, the new superfluids that emerge under confinement might be of interest in quantum computation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project made significant contributions to science and technology in several ways. We first summarize the scientific impact:

3He is the only known superfluid or superconducting system to display different phases in the superfluid state. The transition from the A phase (stable at high pressure and close to the transition temperature) to the B phase stable at lower temperatures and at all temperatures below 21.2 atmospheres pressure, should be forbidden. At these low temperatures, there is no thermal energy available to overcome the barrier to nucleation that arises due to the interfacial energy between the two different phases. Thus, the transition should not occur in a finite time. Yet in the lab it is observed to occur quite reliably. During this research period, we observed that the extent of stability where the A phase exists could be altered depending on the exact path followed while cooling at constant or while varying the pressure. This was exceedingly puzzling. We first concentrated on studies near where the A and B phases have essentially identical energies, and then extended the investigation to larger space in temperature and pressure. We inferred that there must be places in the experimental chamber where, by reason of geometry, the B phase is more stable than the A phase. In turn, these seeds nucleate the B phase in the liquid. Our measurements and model resolve a long standing question relating to this so called heterogenous nucleation.

We used the knowledge gained in this experiment, to design and construct a new arrangement that is free of these seeds of B phase. In our (as yet preliminary) results we see that the B phase nucleates stochastically, that is to say has a somewhat random lifetime likely due to residual radioactivity in our experimental hall or in the apparatus itself. This is heartening, because by further design, we should be able to eliminate or drastically reduce this source of nucleation.

All of these experiments are important because they pertain to transitions that are thought to have occurred in the so-called inflationary epoch of the early universe. The key is that these transitions (termed first order and thus subject to hysteresis) need not happen when a lower energy state presents itself. However, if the transition gets too far from equilibrium (supercooled) it is possible that the lower energy state is never manifested because there is a barrier to the transformation which may be insurmountable. This is essentially identical to the scenario in 3He; thus, 3He, an exotic superfluid system, can provide insights into fundamental processes that must have been present in the early universe.

3He under strong confinement is expected to display new phases and novel physical behaviors such as mass, spin currents that flow along surfaces or edges. This is due to the symmetry of the superfluid state and to the presence of surface bound states trapped at surfaces. We have demonstrated that these surface states can be modified by coating the surface with 4He (the ore common isotope of helium). This quantitative finding enables further studies of confined 3He where new phenomena are expected.

On the technology aspect, we designed and built a miniature ultrasensitive thermometer that has a temperature resolution of better than 50 nK at 1mK. The next generation of this device will be small enough to be incorporated into nanofabricated cells and perform high-precision local thermometry, essential to map out a number of exotic phenomena. We used this device to observe and quantify the presence of superfluid fluctuations in the viscosity just above the superfluid transition temperature. This phenomenon had been predicted fifty years ago but was never observed because of the lack of accurate thermometry.

We have several broader impacts of the research. We advanced the state of the art significantly in terms of small thermometers exhibiting high precision.  The work on 3He (in the field of condensed matter physics) has implications for the distant field of cosmology and the early universe. In addition, our students and postdocs have benefited from international collaborations with Royal Holloway in the UK. The grant resulted in several high-profile publications, contributing to the scientific literature and adding to the knowledge base. The lead post doc (Yefan Tian) is now an imaging specialist in an oil exploration firm in Houston. There were two opportunities for undergraduates from underserved minorities at Cornell. Aldo Chavez is now a PhD student in Materials Science at Stanford, and Joshua McRae is a Junior in the engineering program at Cornell. Thus, the program contributed to the scientific infrastructure through education and training of personnel, additions to the scientific literature, encouragement of the pursuit of STEM literacy, through applications of current technology and for future advances where nanotechnology and flow will be utilized.
